unnormalised: ## Surviving the IIT-JEE Prep: A Guide for the Slightly (Okay, Very) Clueless
normalised: ## Surviving the I-I-T J-E-E Prep: A Guide for the Slightly (Okay, Very) Clueless

unnormalised: So, you've bravely (or foolishly, depending on your perspective) decided to embark on the IIT-JEE journey? Welcome to the club of sleep-deprived, caffeine-fueled zombies. Don't worry, you're not alone. Millions dream of cracking this exam, and statistically, a very small percentage actually do. But hey, who needs statistics when you have delusion, right?
normalised: So, you've bravely (or foolishly, depending on your perspective) decided to embark on the I-I-T J-E-E journey? Welcome to the club of sleep-deprived, caffeine-fueled zombies. Don't worry, you're not alone. Millions dream of cracking this exam, and statistically, a very small percentage actually do. But hey, who needs statistics when you have delusion, right?

unnormalised: First things first, accept the fact that your social life is about to become as extinct as the dodo. Parties? Movies? Hanging out with friends? Those are just distant memories now. Your new best friends are H.C. Verma (the physics guru) and R.D. Sharma (the math magician, or monster, depending on your aptitude). Try to befriend them, they hold the keys (and formulas) to your potential future. Plan on studying at least 10 hrs a day, min. And don't even *think* about pulling an all-nighter right before the exam. Bad idea, trust me.
normalised: First things first, accept the fact that your social life is about to become as extinct as the dodo. Parties? Movies? Hanging out with friends? Those are just distant memories now. Your new best friends are H.C. Verma (the physics guru) and R.D. Sharma (the math magician, or monster, depending on your aptitude). Try to befriend them, they hold the keys (and formulas) to your potential future. Plan on studying at least ten hours a day, minimum. And don't even *think* about pulling an all-nighter right before the exam. Bad idea, trust me.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about coaching classes. Are they necessary? Well, that depends. Are you a child prodigy who can solve complex problems in their sleep? If yes, congratulations, you can probably skip them. For the rest of us mere mortals, a good coaching center like FIITJEE or Allen Career Institute can be invaluable. They’ll give you a structured approach, tons of practice problems, and the illusion that you're actually making progress. And remember, the coaching center fees are only ₹2,00,000+ per year! Bargain!
normalised: Now, let's talk about coaching classes. Are they necessary? Well, that depends. Are you a child prodigy who can solve complex problems in their sleep? If yes, congratulations, you can probably skip them. For the rest of us mere mortals, a good coaching center like F-I-I-T-J-E-E or Allen Career Institute can be invaluable. They’ll give you a structured approach, tons of practice problems, and the illusion that you're actually making progress. And remember, the coaching center fees are only rupee two hundred thousand plus per year! Bargain!

unnormalised: The syllabus? Oh, the syllabus. It's basically a compilation of everything you've ever learned in science and math, plus a few extra topics just to mess with you. Don't even attempt to memorize everything. Focus on understanding the concepts. And for the love of all that is holy, practice, practice, practice! Solve problems until your fingers ache and your eyes bleed. Aim for 100+ questions per topic. Just kidding...sort of.
normalised: The syllabus? Oh, the syllabus. It's basically a compilation of everything you've ever learned in science and math, plus a few extra topics just to mess with you. Don't even attempt to memorize everything. Focus on understanding the concepts. And for the love of all that is holy, practice, practice, practice! Solve problems until your fingers ache and your eyes bleed. Aim for one hundred plus questions per topic. Just kidding...sort of.

unnormalised: But hey, it's not all doom and gloom. There will be moments of triumph, like when you finally solve that one ridiculously difficult problem after hours of struggling. Or when you score better than Sharmaji's son on a mock test. These small victories are what keep you going. So celebrate them, even if it's just with a small packet of Maggi and a cup of chai.
normalised: But hey, it's not all doom and gloom. There will be moments of triumph, like when you finally solve that one ridiculously difficult problem after hours of struggling. Or when you score better than Sharmaji's son on a mock test. These small victories are what keep you going. So celebrate them, even if it's just with a small packet of Maggi and a cup of chai.

unnormalised: Remember to take breaks. Seriously. Your brain needs time to recharge. Go for a walk, listen to music, or watch a funny video. Just don't spend the entire break scrolling through social media and comparing yourself to others. That's a recipe for disaster. Set a timer, say 20 mins max for these mini-breaks. And NO screens before bed, capiche?
normalised: Remember to take breaks. Seriously. Your brain needs time to recharge. Go for a walk, listen to music, or watch a funny video. Just don't spend the entire break scrolling through social media and comparing yourself to others. That's a recipe for disaster. Set a timer, say twenty minutes maximum for these mini-breaks. And N-O screens before bed, capiche?

unnormalised: Finally, don't forget to breathe. The IIT-JEE is a tough exam, but it's not the end of the world. If you don't crack it, there are plenty of other options out there. Life goes on. Just try your best, stay positive (or at least mildly optimistic), and remember to laugh along the way. After all, what's life without a little bit of absurdity? You got this (maybe) ... or at least you'll have a really good story to tell at parties later on. Good luck, and may the odds be ever in your favour, or at least slightly better than your neighbour's!
normalised: Finally, don't forget to breathe. The I-I-T J-E-E is a tough exam, but it's not the end of the world. If you don't crack it, there are plenty of other options out there. Life goes on. Just try your best, stay positive (or at least mildly optimistic), and remember to laugh along the way. After all, what's life without a little bit of absurdity? You got this (maybe) ... or at least you'll have a really good story to tell at parties later on. Good luck, and may the odds be ever in your favour, or at least slightly better than your neighbour's!
